description.narrative: By 2021, there will have been improvements to prevention programmes and strategies for physical and sexual violence, particularly against female adolescents and girls, at school and in the family, in the priority territories., which contributes to Access To Justice, Child Protection And Emergencies, Child Protection â€“ Strengthen Families And Communities, Data And Child Protection, Equitable Access To Quality Education, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children, Prevention And Response Services For Violence Against Children (Covid), Violence, Exploitation And Abuse. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Evaluations, Research And Data, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2021, children and adolescents will be brought up and educated without violence and will access services that guarantee their protection and access to justice

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2021, there will have been improvements to prevention programmes and strategies for physical and sexual violence, particularly against female adolescents and girls, at school and in the family, in the priority territories.

description.narrative: Peru has data on violence against children in schools. The MoE is preventing violence by teachers (corporal punishment and sexual harassment or abuse) and by other school children (physical and sexual violence and bullying) by improving school climate and fostering positive teaching practices. Principals have clear guidelines for handling cases of violence. Non-violent parenting practices were included in workshops targeting ECD service providers. Community mental health practitioners are better skilled to handle trauma in children under 3 years of age and the MoH has a standardized protocol of assistance for child survivors of sexual violence at health facilities. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:31/12/2019

title.narrative: Number of social programs to support families and children who have incorporated validated strategies that promote non-violent parenting practices.

target.value: 2021:At least 1 program in level 5 (Implementation of strategy is on course) and 1 in level 4 (There is a formally approved strategy)

actual.value:
2019:PNCM: Family Care Service (Level 2)
MoH: Strategy with Community Mental Health Centres (Level 1)

title.narrative: Number of children, parents and primary caregivers provided with community based mental health and psychosocial support and messaging [COVIDSitRep]

Level of implementation of validated strategies of prevention and response to physical, sexual and gender-based violence in the educational establishments of the prioritized areas, developed by the education sector.

baseline.value: There is a national strategy on school violence centered on peer violence, which does not address adult physical and sexual violence against children and adolescents.

target.value: 2021:At least 1 strategy in level 4 (Implementation in prioritized regions)

actual.value: 2019:Level 3: Commitments have been made to the MINEDU for the implementation and validation of the strategy for preventing and responding to school violence through the teams deployed in the Regional Education Directorates and Local Management Units.
